Questions: What are the symptoms of Parkinson's Disease?
Reponses:
The most common symptoms of Parkinson’s disease include:

- Tremor (shaking) in hands, arms, legs, jaw or face that occurs when the limb is at rest.
- Slowness of movement.
- Stiffness and rigidity of muscles.
- Problems with balance and walking.

How can you prevent Parkinson's Disease?

Parkinson’s disease is a chronic, progressive neurological disorder that affects the brain’s ability to control movement. While there is no cure for Parkinson’s disease, research shows that lifestyle changes may help reduce your risk of developing the condition.

- Get enough exercise: A 2016 study published in JAMA Neurology found that a high level of physical activity could lower your risk of developing Parkinson’s disease by up to 35 percent.
- Eat a healthy diet: Research shows that eating certain foods and supplements, including blueberries, omega-3 fatty acids and coffee may reduce the risk of developing Parkinson’s disease.
- Stay social: Social isolation is a common problem among older adults with Parkinson’s disease.
Reponses_Attendues: Treatment includes medications (levodopa) and deep brain stimulation.

Questions: How is HIV/AIDS diagnosed?
Reponses:
The virus is present in blood and can be detected through antibody testing. The test for HIV infection detects the presence of antibodies to the virus that cause HIV/AIDS in blood and saliva (by fingerstick or mouth swab). Antibodies are proteins produced by the immune system in response to a foreign substance, such as a virus.

The test is usually done on a sample of blood taken from a vein in your arm. The test can also be performed with an oral specimen obtained using an absorbent cotton pad applied inside your cheek and mouth (an oropharyngeal swab). The swab is then placed into a vial containing preservative fluid, which allows the sample to be sent to the laboratory for testing.

The test can also be done with a fingerstick blood specimen collected from a drop of blood obtained by pricking your fingertip with a lancet (a small needle). The fingerstick blood is placed into a vial containing preservative fluid, which allows the sample to be sent to the laboratory for testing. The tests performed in both oral and fingerstick blood specimens detect the same HIV antibodies as those detected in blood from a vein
Reponses_Attendues: Treatment includes antiretroviral therapy (ART) to control the virus.

## What is Dengue Fever?

Dengue fever is a viral infection transmitted by the bite of an infected mosquito. It causes high fever, headache, muscle and joint pains, and a characteristic skin rash. The disease is caused by any one of four related dengue viruses. These viruses are transmitted to humans through the bites of infected Aedes mosquitoes.

Dengue fever is also known as breakbone fever because it can cause severe joint and muscle pain that feels like bones are breaking. The disease is common in tropical and subtropical areas, including parts of Africa, Asia, the Pacific Islands, and Latin America. Deng
Reponses_Attendues: Diagnosis involves blood tests to detect the virus or its antibodies.

Questions: Can Glaucoma be prevented?
Reponses:
Yes, if it is detected early and treated promptly.

What are the symptoms of glaucoma?

There are no symptoms in the early stages of glaucoma. The disease usually progresses slowly over many years. As a result, you may not notice any change in your vision until the condition has reached an advanced stage. By then, irreversible damage to the optic nerve may have occurred. This is why it is important to have regular eye examinations so that glaucoma can be detected and treated early.

What are the risk factors for glaucoma?

The most common risk factor for glaucoma is increasing age. Other risk factors include a family history of glaucoma, certain ethnic groups (African-Americans, Hispanics), previous eye injury or surgery, and use of corticosteroid medications.

Can anyone develop glaucoma?

Yes. Glaucoma can affect anyone, but it is more common in people over 40 years old. People with a family history of glaucoma are at greater risk for developing the disease.

How is glaucoma treated?

Reponses_Attendues: Preventing Glaucoma involves regular eye exams and maintaining eye health.

Questions: Can Endometriosis be prevented?
Reponses:
Can you prevent endometriosis? Yes and No. While there is no way to completely prevent endometriosis, there are ways to reduce your risk of developing the condition.

What is endometriosis?

Endometriosis is a chronic inflammatory disease in which cells that line the uterus grow outside the uterine cavity, and often spreads into the ovaries and other parts of the abdominal cavity. It is believed to be an autoimmune condition where the immune system does not recognize endometrial tissue as foreign, so it allows the endometrial cells to proliferate without attack or inflammation, similar to that observed with breast and uterine cancers (Fazio 1989; Azziz et al. 2004).

Endometriosis is a very common condition affecting approximately 5-10% of women in the reproductive age group. It is one of the most common causes of infertility and chronic pelvic pain, and is associated with many other health problems including: painful periods, irregular bleeding, painful intercourse, infertility, ovarian cysts
Reponses_Attendues: Endometriosis is caused by the abnormal growth of tissue outside the uterus.

Questions: How is Cancer diagnosed?
Reponses:
A combination of several tests are used to diagnose cancer. These include:

- Physical examination
- Blood and urine tests
- X-rays, mammography and CAT Scan, bone scans or nuclear magnetic resonance (MRN) test – also known as NMRI in short (which uses radio waves to create images of organs and tissues)
- Endoscopy
- Biopsy

A biopsy involves surgical removal of some tissues suspected of having malignant cells. The tissue is then examined under a microscope by a pathologist who will determine if the cancer is present and, if so, what type it is. This helps to determine the stage or extent of the disease and also its prognosis.

How is Cancer treated?
Treatment depends on the type of cancer and may involve:

- Surgery to remove part of a malignant tumour and a wide area around it so as not to spread to other parts of the body.
- Radiation therapy which uses high energy rays to kill cancer cells.
- Chemotherapy which involves using drugs to destroy cancer cells.
- Hormone therapy which is used to treat
Reponses_Attendues: Symptoms vary depending on the type and stage of cancer.

Questions: What treatment options are available for Endometriosis?
Reponses:
Treatment for endometriosis is determined by the severity of your symptoms. For patients whose discomfort may not need extensive interventions and surgical correction can begin to seek over the counter analgesic medicine from doctors (asthma, arthritis, etc.) or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen and naproxen sodium. NSAIDS reduce prostaglandins (prostaglandins cause the cramping, pain, and inflammation associated with endometriosis).

If your symptoms are more severe, your doctor may prescribe hormonal contraceptives to prevent ovulation. This can help decrease menstrual bleeding and cramps as well as relieve other symptoms such as diarrhea. Doctors prescribed high dose NSAID combinations containing birth control medication because the drug reduces the levels of estrogen, which can lead to infertility in women who are under 27 years old at conception and cause endometriosis in postmenopausal women.

Another treatment option for severe endometriosis is hormone replacement therapy (HRT). This form
Reponses_Attendues: Managing Endometriosis involves pain management, hormonal therapies, and surgical interventions.

Questions: How can I manage my Diabetes?
Reponses:
Type 1 and type 2 diabetes are both chronic conditions that require daily management. The good news is that there are many ways to help you manage your diabetes, including:

- Follow your care team's treatment plan: The healthcare team caring for your condition is composed of primary physicians who focus on a certain field like diabetology, endocrinology, internal medicine, or family medicine. They will work with you to develop a treatment plan that works best for you and helps you achieve the goals you have set.
- Follow a healthy eating plan: The dietitian is an important member of your healthcare team because he/she helps create meal plans for your type of diabetes based on the nutrition information and foods that will keep you as healthy as possible while staying within a range that doesn’t exceed certain numbers of carbs or sugar levels at different times of the day, according to American Diabetes Association guidelines (1). It can also include making simple adjustments to cooking techniques when using oil vs. fat/protein instead which might lead people with diabetes into eating more calories than they need without realizing it!
- Get regular exercise: Exercise is an important part of managing your diabetes because it helps control blood sugar levels,
Reponses_Attendues: Medication adherence, blood sugar monitoring.

Questions: How is Dengue Fever diagnosed?
Reponses:
- Clinical history and physical examination.
- Laboratory tests:
    - Complete blood count (CBC) with differential.
    - Peripheral blood smear, especially thick and thin blood films stained by the Giemsa stain.
    - Serologic testing for IgM antibodies to dengue virus.
    - Virus isolation from serum or plasma by cell culture or molecular techniques.
- Other tests:
    - Chest X-ray, ECG and echocardiogram if pulmonary or cardiac complications are suspected.

Which specimen type should I use to collect blood?

Venipuncture is the preferred method for collecting blood for laboratory testing.

How long will it take to get results?

Results of a rapid test are usually available within 30 minutes; serological and virological tests can take from several days up to a few weeks depending on the assay used and whether samples are tested locally or referred to reference laboratories.
Reponses_Attendues: Lifestyle changes include avoiding alcohol, practicing safe sex, and maintaining a healthy diet.

How are Parkinson's Disease and Parkinson's Syndrome different?

Parkinson's Disease is a chronic progressive neurological condition that causes a wide range of symptoms including tremors, rigid muscles, slowed movement, and impaired balance. Parkinson's Syndrome is a set of symptoms that can be caused by other neurological conditions, such as multiple sclerosis or brain tumors.

What are the different types of Parkinson's Disease?

  1. Idiopathic Parkinson's Disease: This type of Parkinson's Disease has no known cause.
  2. Secondary Parkinson's Disease: This type of Parkinson's Disease is caused by another medical condition, such as a brain tumor or stroke.
  3. Mixed Parkinson's Disease: This type of Parkinson's Disease is caused by both Parkinson's Disease and another medical condition, such as Alzheimer's Disease.
  4. Drug-Induced Parkinson's Disease: This type of Parkinson's Disease is caused by taking certain medications, such as antidepressants or antihistamines.

## Treatment

HIV/AIDS treatment is primarily focused on managing symptoms, preventing infection, and slowing the progression of the disease.

### Medications

Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is the primary treatment for HIV/AIDS. This involves taking a combination of antiretroviral medications to reduce the amount of HIV in the body and prevent its spread.

### Lifestyle modifications

Lifestyle modifications, such as regular exercise and a healthy diet, can also help to manage HIV/AIDS.

### Palliative care

Palliative care is an important part of HIV/AIDS treatment, as it focuses on providing comfort and relief to patients with advanced disease.

## Prevention

Preventing the spread of HIV/AIDS is an important part of HIV/AIDS treatment.

### Safe sex

Safe sex is the most effective way to prevent the spread of HIV/AIDS. This involves using a condom during sexual intercourse to prevent contact with bodily fluids.

### Needle and syringe programs

Needle and syringe programs are programs that provide clean and sterile needles and syringes to people who inject drugs. These programs are an important part of HIV/AIDS prevention, as they reduce the risk of HIV transmission among people who inject drugs.

### Testing and counseling

Testing and counseling are important for HIV/AIDS prevention. People who are at risk for HIV infection should be tested regularly to monitor their status and receive counseling on how to prevent infection.

### Vaccines

There are currently no vaccines available for HIV/AIDS prevention. However, research is ongoing to develop a vaccine for preventing HIV infection.

## Research

HIV/AIDS research is an important part of HIV/AIDS treatment and prevention.

### Basic research

Basic research is ongoing to understand the biology of HIV/AIDS. This includes research on the structure and function of HIV, as well as research
Reponses_Attendues: Treatment includes antiretroviral therapy (ART) to control the virus.

Questions: Can Glaucoma be prevented?
Reponses:
<s> Can Glaucoma be prevented?

   The answer is YES. There are ways to reduce the risk of glaucoma.

   There are many factors that can increase the risk of developing glaucoma. Some of these are:

- Age: Glaucoma is more common in older people. The risk increases as we get older.

- Ethnicity: Glaucoma is more common in people of African and Caribbean descent.

- Family history: Glaucoma is more likely to run in families.

- Eye injury: Injuries to the eye can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Other medical conditions: Some medical conditions, such as diabetes, can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Low blood pressure: Low blood pressure can increase the risk of glaucoma.

- Smoking: Smoking can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- High myopia: High myopia (short-sightedness) can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Steroids: Steroids can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Other factors: Other factors, such as a family history of glaucoma, can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Medication: Some medications, such as beta-blockers, can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Eye drops: Eye drops that are used to lower the pressure in the eye can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Eye surgery: Eye surgery that is used to lower the pressure in the eye can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Eye injuries: Eye injuries can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Eye infections: Eye infections can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Eye inflammation: Eye inflammation can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Eye tumors: Eye tumors can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Eye trauma: Eye trauma can increase the risk of developing glaucoma.

- Eye diseases: Eye diseases, such as catar

Questions: How can I manage my Diabetes?
Reponses:
<s> How can I manage my Diabetes?

  

## What is Diabetes?

Diabetes is a condition in which the body has a problem with producing insulin. Insulin is a hormone that helps our body to convert carbohydrates into energy. When a person has Diabetes, the body is not able to produce enough insulin, or in some cases, no insulin at all. This causes blood glucose levels to rise and the body is not able to use glucose for energy.

## Types of Diabetes

There are two types of Diabetes:

1. Type 1 Diabetes
2. Type 2 Diabetes

### Type 1 Diabetes

Type 1 Diabetes is a condition in which the body is not able to produce insulin. This is a genetic condition and it usually occurs in childhood. It is estimated that 5% to 10% of all people with Diabetes have Type 1.

### Type 2 Diabetes

Type 2 Diabetes is a condition in which the body is not able to use insulin properly. This is a metabolic condition and it usually occurs in adulthood. It is estimated that 90% to 95% of all people with Diabetes have Type 2.

## Symptoms

The symptoms of Diabetes may include:

* Increased thirst
* Increased urination
* Unusual weight loss
* Fatigue
* Blurred vision
* Tingling or numbness in the feet
* Dry skin

## Prevention

There is no cure for Diabetes, but there are things that you can do to prevent it.

### Avoid smoking and alcohol

Smoking and alcohol can both increase your risk for Diabetes. If you are a smoker, it is important to quit smoking. If you drink alcohol, it is important to do so in moderation.

### Eat healthy

Eating healthy is one of the best ways to prevent Diabetes. You should avoid eating foods that are high in sugar and saturated fat. Instead, eat foods that are low in sugar and saturated fat and high
Reponses_Attendues: Medication adherence, blood sugar monitoring.
